titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. IV. Thursday.

Called again from my garden exercise, by a visit from Augustus Whitney second Son of the Minister of the Parish, who is to be graduated at the approaching Commencement— I labour less in the Nursery than heretofore, but planted a row of nuts, cherry-stones and seeds this morning— The rain has recovered some of the drooping plants— Others are irretrievably gone— I attempt to write on my biographical essay but it labours— I read the papers of the controversies from the time of the Stamp Act, between Sir Francis Bernard, and the General Court of Massachusetts, and part of those which succeeded, with Hutchinson first as Lieutenant Governor and then as Governor.— I read also in part Hutchinson’s account of these disputes in the 3d. Volume of his History— One man always contends to extreme disadvantage against many, but Bernard appears to have been a shallow conceited Englishman, full of Vanity and self-importance— Hutchinson was an abler man, but not a wiser one— They were both brought by their official positions into the conflicts which ruined their reputations; but Hutchinson had the additional misfortune of being engaged in a contest against his native Country— I walked towards Evening, and read a few Letters of Sevigné
2 IV. Friday.

On the second of August 1779. this day fifty-four years elapsed I landed with my father from the French frigate La Sensible, on the Beach of the Mount Wollaston farm from which I had eighteen months before, on the 11th. of February 1778 embarked for France on my first Voyage to Europe— This is one of the important anniversaries of my life; and through how many Scenes of good and of evil fortune have I since passed— How many of deep distress? how many of exquisite enjoyment— How many of severe trial—how many of painful and pleasant labour—how many of overruling passion—and how few of virtuous self-denial and of disinterested exertion for the good of my fellow creatures. I cannot dare to say like Rousseau of Geneva that I am prepared to present myself before the throne of omnipotence with my confessions in my hand, and affirm that no better man than myself ever lived. There have been better because there have been incomparably wiser men— I have little to answer for in my relations with mankind, and have a firm though humble reliance on the mercy of my maker— A return of rhumatic infirmity this day gave me a new admonition to prepare for the close of life— Mr Minot Thayer was here this morning, and introduced a young man by the name of Strong—a Grandson of Simeon Strong of Amherst, whom I remember as once a Judge of the Supreme Court of the Commonwealth— I visited my Garden and Nursery but was disabled from working much— The young trees are ceasing their growth for the Season.
3. IV. Saturday.

Sharp touch of Sciatica or Lumbago, which breaks me down for labour both of body and mind. Francis Williams the tax-collector and Benjamin Bass were here together— Williams gave me my tax-bill for this present year amounting to 419 dollars 80 cents, of which 180 dollars and 70 cents are for parish-tax— He spoke to me of the balance of the last year’s bill, which I told him I would pay. Bass settled with me for the Interest of his Note to me; for a year to the 7th. of July. Mrs Adams,
Charles and his wife went to Boston, and all returned to dinner.— In the Nursery, at the lower end, next to the old Apple tree, I found a seedling walnut tree, just appearing above the surface— It is one of a row in which there are now three walnuts and two Oaks. I planted by the side of it a row of Ohio Walnuts, Mazzard Cherry Stones, 1 Apricot Stone, and crushed whortleberries and currants kneaded up in dry Garden Soil— I have here and there a Currant Bush, Vine, Raspberry, Blackberry and Thimbleberry plants from the seed; but as yet no Whortleberry— I have planted whole berries; but now try the seeds disengaged from them.— Of three seedling Cherry-trees at the bottom of the Nursery, two have been killed by the drought and heat. Towards evening I walked to Mr Quincy’s gate— Read Massachusetts State-papers, and the third Volume of Hutchinson’s History—but could not write—
4. IV:45. Sunday— Sun rises at 5.

Heard Mr P. Whitney, from Matthew 10.38. [“]And he that taketh not his cross, and followeth after me, is not worthy of me”— After the Sermon, Mr Whitney administered the Communion— His text after dinner was from Job 14.14. “All the days of my appointed time will I wait, till my change come.” a discourse upon death and immortality— The argument of immortality from the transformations of insects is plausible but superficial— The transmutations of matter are perpetual standing miracles; but a resurrection of living matter after a dissolution of all its parts is not one of the phenomena of ordinary nature— Of disembodied Spirit we have no evidence except miracles—the transformation of insects is no evidence of it whatever. A thunder-shower came up in the midst of the afternoon Service. Charles and I rode home. It continued for more than an hour afterwards— I read the 3d. Sermon of Saurin’s 4th Volume, on the Devotion of Sentiment from Psalm 63.5.— A parallel between Religion, as a dictate of Reason and Judgment, and that which comes from the heart— It is in many respect the difference between the Religion of the Catholic and the Protestant Churches— But it is not considered in this light by Saurin— He was a Protestant—a refugee from the persecuting Religion of Louis 14— In his Sermon upon Patriotism, he refers directly to the condition of the French Refugees—but he never indulges in declamations against popery, and alludes if at all, only indirectly to the Tyranny of Louis 14— I was suffering severe pain last Night, and all this day with cette Sciatique—sympathising with the state of the atmosphere.
5. V. Monday

Another painful day, with a gathering eruption upon my right hand— It suspends most of my labours of the hand in the garden and Nursery and of the head in my chamber. Mrs Adams sent for Dr Woodward, to whom I gave a history of my complaints, of my Constitution and almost of my life— He prescribed sundry remedies, some of which I shall perhaps try; but with a strong conviction that my only effectual remedies are Patience and Resignation; and above all preparation for my last change— If this idea presents itself too often in these pages, it is because it is not often enough in my mind; and never with any good practical result— My present infirmity serves me only as an apology for wasting my time in idleness— I have for the last ten days devoted about an hour every day to teaching my Grand daughter, John’s Child Louisa, to read the Alphabet— She seems to make no progress, though not deficient in intelligence— I find here too that the qualities perhaps the most indispensable to a Schoolmaster are Patience and Perseverance— After repetitions almost numberless of pointing out the same Letter or the same Syllable to a child, it forgets them; and it seems as if the more pains you take the more the memory of the child recalcitrates against the admission of the idea into the mind, which you would plant there— I sometimes find
myself to believe it wilful obstinacy in the child—but in the teacher this is more to blame than the child for its inaptitude to learn— The belief that the child is obstinate excites anger in the teacher, and anger is impatient to punish— The teacher is then the party that needs punishment— Soothing, coaxing, flattering, a little, very little shaming is needed by the child. Imperturbable equanimity, untiring Patience, unweariable Perseverance are the wants of the Instructor— What trials of temper for the teaching of one child— When I feel much exasperated at my Scholar’s dulness of apprehension, my best resource is to tax myself with learning the Hebrew Alphabet, which I have been endeavouring to do, some forty odd years, and have not yet accomplished— The thickest skull upon which Instruction ever lost its labour never resisted its impression more than mine has done to exclude it, and as the association of ideas is sometimes odd in its operations— Louisa’s difficulties in learning the English Alphabet have put me for the twentieth, perhaps the thirtieth time upon surmounting those of the Hebrew. I make my own indocility the apology for hers.
6. V. Tuesday—

The day is a blank in my Life. With a stricture of severe pain across my loins, and a poultice on my right hand I have but a poor account to give of my occupations—and only wasted the time— But yesterday and this day were both anniversaries of the dies fasti of my life— Yesterday was twenty-four years, since I embarked in the ship Horace, Captain Beckford, at Charlestown for St. Petersburg; and this day sixteen years since, I landed at New-York, from the Ship Washington, Captain Forman, from London and Cowes where I embarked on my return from that residence in Europe— I went out as Minister of the United States at the Court of the Emperor Alexander of Russia; I returned as Secretary of State of the United States— Eight years of diplomacy in Europe, in various important negotiations, in critical and trying times, eight years in the Department of State, followed by four years as President of the United States, constitute the most active period of my existence— The last four years have been comparatively insignificant, and I have only to pray that the remnant of my days may be marked with equal tranquility. I belong to the age that has past, and can look forward with rational hopes or wishes only for an euthanasia. It was with great difficulty that I wrote my morning minutes from the Septuagint of Charles Thomson, and the diary of yesterday— I visited the garden and nursery, only to view the flourishing prosperity of numberless rank weeds— My Grand child pupil was unwell and missed her reading— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. I read nearly half the Volume of Mr Rush’s Memoranda, of his Residence in England— Fresh morning Shower.
7. V. Wednesday

Mr Whitney the Minister paid me a morning visit. His eldest daughter, Caroline, is to be married the 20th. of this month to a Mr Hill of Roxbury— There were heavy Showers of rain in the night and this morning— This moisture has very much revived the vegetation—which was drooping and perishing with drought— I visited my garden and Nursery, but my hand being crippled could not work— The white elm is so easy to raise from the seed, that I have them shooting up not only where I planted the seeds in rows, but single trees in every part
of the Nursery or Garden, where I happened to drop a seed. There is very great difference however in the rapidity of their growth, and like other seedlings when first up they require shelter from the Sun— Four at least in five of the first row which came up have been killed— I remark that my seedling Pear trees, of last year, the roots of which have been protected, by my seedling Strawberry vine, without growing much, look fresher and healthier than any others— My Apple shoots from buds and grafts have ceased growing from about the first of this Month— All the white Ashes have been topp’d by Insects— The bugs are also making free with my Vine-leaves— From some of my red Oaks a third shoot appears from about the first of this Month— I am still greatly though not entirely disabled from writing— Charles found among my fathers papers some additional old original diaries, of the years 1769—1770—1771—and 1772. I read them all this afternoon—
8. V. Thursday.

list.item: His wife, and youngest daughter Georgiana Frances

div.p: The Rhumatism across my back, and the inflammation upon the back of my right hand continues and increases in severity— It was with extreme difficulty that I wrote the minutes of this morning, and the diary of yesterday— I visited my garden and Nursery with helpless hand— Amidst swarms of weeds I found two stems just up—the first up from the multitude of seeds that I planted of the white beech— I must welcome one of several hundreds—and it is one planted last May— Of those planted last fall not one has come up— This afternoon shortly before Sunset, my Son John arrived here with his wife; his second daughter Georgiana Frances, her Nurse Mrs Goode, and the black boy Alfred. They have been spending a fortnight at Long-Branch, and came from New-York yesterday afternoon.— Joseph Nash of Weymouth a Soldier and applicant for a Revolutionary Pension was here, and requested me to obtain for him an answer from the Secretary of War— I promised to write, and asked him to call here again in about three weeks— I read over part of my father’s Autobiography.
9. V:15. Friday.

Rainy night and morning— Cold and cloudy day—clearing off towards Evening. In the multitudinous whimsies of a disabled mind and body, the thick coming fancies often occur to me that the events which affect my life and adventures are specially shaped to disappoint my purposes— My whole life has been a succession of disappointments— I can scarcely recollect a single instance of success to any thing that I ever undertook. Yet with fervent Gratitude to God, I confess that my life has been equally marked by great and signal successes, which I neither aimed at nor anticipated— Fortune, by which I understand Providence has showered blessings upon me profusely— But they have been blessings unforeseen and unsought— Non Nobis Domine, non Nobis sed nomini tuo da gloriam. I ought to have been taught by it three lessons— 1 Of implicit reliance upon Providence 2. Of humility and humiliation—the thorough conviction of my own impotence to accomplish any thing. 3. Of Resignation—and not to set my heart upon any thing which can be taken from me or denied— I can now do scarcely anything but read, and I read the remaining sheets of the Autobiography of my father, which comes down only to October 1776. I lament that he did not continue it— I have also finished Mr. Rush’s Volume upon his Residence in London.
10. V.15. Saturday

I persist in daily writing at this diary, when I can scarcely trace a line in legible characters— When I cease it must be from the impossibility of writing at all—but I was obliged to use my wife’s hand to write two short Letters—and to send again for Dr Woodward who came and lanced the boil on the back of my right hand, which I am poulticing with bread and milk and beet-leaves alternately— My Sciatica likewise continues. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine— Louisa Smith and Elizabeth Adams were here this afternoon—and I walked for exercise to the 6th. Milestone— Read some of my fathers old diaries.
11. V:15. Sunday.

Heard Mr George Whitney this morning from Luke 10.27. [“]And he answering said, Thou shalt love the Lord thy God, with all thy heart, and with all thy Soul, and with all thy strength, and with all thy mind, and thy neighbour as thyself.”— And in the afternoon from John 17.17 “Sanctify them through thy truth: thy word is truth.” These were both argumentative Discourses—well written—well composed—well divided, well reasoned, and well delivered— The first on the indissoluble connection and indispensable union of piety and morality, for the perfection of the Christian character— The other upon the character of the Gospel as the word of Truth— Mr George Whitney improves as he advances in years, and if he perseveres with industry and vigilance on his studies, will make a shining character— Mr Degrand was here to tea; and Coll. and Mrs. and Edmund Quincy in the Evening— Dr Woodward was here early this morning, and prescribed poultice and Plaister for my hand— I am still disabled, and in much pain— I read the 4th. Sermon of the 4th. Volume of Saurin—upon Holiness, which pleased me less than any other of his that I have read. It is exceedingly metaphysical and refined, and the reasoning though subtle and ingenious, but not satisfactory. I read also part of two chapters of Milman’s History of the Jews—with which I am better pleased than I had anticipated.
12. 5.15. Monday.

Mrs Quincy, the President’s Lady and Miss Abigail Quincy, her daughter, with her Grand-child Josiah, paid our Ladies a morning visit— My hands and my hips are still crippled, and still yield me from the dust of Earth an apology for idleness, and I do nothing. The Parish Meeting was adjourned to this day at 5 O’Clock in the afternoon. I attended and acted again as Moderator. The meeting was very thin— Mr Beale the Treasurer made a Report of the debts and means of the Parish— The Subscription for the payment of the debt exceeds 2200 dollars, and with the offer that I have made to take the pews now unsold in payment of the debt of 3000 dollars due to me, makes ample provision for sweeping off the whole debt, with the exception of that due for pews sold and partly paid for, but of which the purchasers neither complete their payments nor give up their pews. These have done nothing— A vote was passed directing the Treasurer to call upon those Pewholders for settlement, and to take possession in the name of the Parish of all the pews which shall not be paid for, or security given to the Satisfaction of the Treasurer and Parish Committee, and deeds taken, on or before
the last day of this Month; and that he also collect the monies subscribed, by that day, and make report on the execution of this Resolution at the adjournment of the Meeting. And the Meeting was adjourned to Monday the 2d. of September at 4. O’Clock in the afternoon— I stated distinctly to the Parish what I would do— After all the rest of the Parish debt shall be paid, and not before, I will take the remaining 30 Pews in full payment of the debt to me of 3000 dollars—and to specify precisely what I consider the amount of this offer to be, I engaged to transfer all those pews to any person or company who would pay me for them in cash, with a deduction of 20 per Cent from the price at which I propose to take them— It is therefore an offer of 600 dollars, as my contribution to pay the parish debt— Walked home with Thomas and Daniel Greenleaf— My Son John trimm’d a number of the Peach-trees in my Garden and Nursery—picked out the worms from their Roots which he white washed, and surrounded with Ashes— I substituted this day a salve for a poultice on the back of my hand— Hungry visitor this Evening.
13. V. Tuesday.

Sultry, showery day— Canicular— It was the birth day of our Son Charles’s daughter Louisa who is two years old. I am yet almost disabled from writing, and my visits to my Garden and Nursery, only serve for discovery of what ought to be done, and what I cannot do— I resumed with my Son Charles the collating of my father’s old diaries with the copy of part of them which I have had made in volumes— Mr Whitney’s two daughters and his son Augustus paid us an Evening visit.— The only occupations which I have not discontinued are, the continuance of this diary from day to day, and the morning minutes of my reading of Charles Thomson’s Septuagint— The more I study this book, the more it excites in me of amazement— The more I find of incomprehensible narratives— One of the Stories which most perplexes me is that of the prophet who at the time of the building of Jeroboam’s altar at Bethel predicts that it will be destroyed by a king named Josiah, which prophesy is accomplished more than 300 years afterwards— The extraordinary conduct and fate of this prophet— The utter uselessness of his prophesy to any purpose which it might have served— The fraud practised upon him by another prophet, which causes his destruction, and the affectionate attachment to him of the prophet who deceived him and caused his destruction, but who insists upon being buried in the same grave with him; all this is so strange and wonderful that I know not what to make of it— I close the volume in despair.
14. V. Wednesday.— Boston— Quincy to dine.

I went with my Son Charles to Boston this morning, and after calling at Mr James H. Foster’s, where I saw Mrs Foster and their daughter Mary, and at Mr Alexander H. Everett’s, and having an hour’s conversation with him, I went with him and attended a Meeting of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences— Very thinly attended—not more than 15 members present— A Letter from some foreign Literary Society was read; and there was the first Volume of the new Series of the Transactions of the Society ready for delivery— A new nomination book was produced, the old one being lost— I entered upon it the name of the Revd Nathaniel L Frothingham for Election as a member— Among the most striking Evidences of the apathy into which this Society has fallen is the fact, that not one of the younger eminent Clergymen of Boston
is now a member— I added my name also to several others proposing Coll. Thayer the late Commandant at West-Point, for election— Mr T. L. Winthrop invited me to dine with him to-morrow—with the two Commissioners of the Navy and Secretary of the Navy Woodbury now here; but I declined— The meeting was dissolved soon after noon. I went to Charles’s Office— Then visited a group of Statues representing Burns’s Tam O’Shanter, in coarse Scottish free-stone, by a self-taught artist named Thom, well executed, and returned home to Quincy to dine— Mr Alexander H. Everett had requested a conversation with me, and it was to urge me to consent to be nominated for election as Governor of the Commonwealth, which I persisted in declining.— He thought they could not agree upon his brother Edward, but gave me no substantial reason for changing my determination— After dinner my Classmate the Revd. Dr Harris came to see me— His object was to enquire if it was probable Congress would grant any thing by way of indemnity to the sufferers by the Revolutionary War— He said his father was an inhabitant of Charlestown at the time of the conflagration of that place, and had been burnt out of house and home and profession for subsistence— He kept a school. I thought Congress would be afraid of opening so wide a door of claims.
15. IV:15. Thursday.

I rose this morning by early twilight, the sky being perfectly clear to look for the Star Sirius now issued from his conjunction with the Sun— But he was not to be discovered with the naked eye— My Son John has given a thorough trimming to my young Peach trees— There are two Oaks and seven pignut hickories up, from nuts and acorns which I planted last October in a Row near the lowest Old Apple-tree in my Nursery— Of the Hickories three have come up since the first of this Month— I perceive by then very distinctly from the first appearance of the plant, the difference between the Shellbark and the pignut— I compared with my Son Charles some pages of my father’s old Journals, with the copies, in 3 Volumes— I hear my Grand daughter Mary Louisa read, and have reached the first Book of Chronicles in Thomsons Septuagint— Mr Beale was here this Evening with his daughter Ann— My hand is still crippled and my rhumatism painful.
16. V. Friday

The lameness of my hand, and the rhumatism disable me so that my time slips away leaving my life a blank— Mr Price Greenleaf came this afternoon and budded for me, four Stocks of Mazzard Cherry trees. I found a nest of Palmer-worms upon one of my young seedling Apple trees— The most thrifty growth that I have is the button-wood twig, which I set out as a Stake in the Nursery in Novr 1830. This afternoon Mr Alexander H. Everett came out and introduced the Marquis Torrigiani, a young Italian Nobleman from Florence—who is travelling in the United States for amusement and Instruction: a modest and sensible young Man. He arrived in New-York about the middle of March last, and has visited the Western States of Ohio and Kentucky— But the prevalence of the Cholera on the river towns of the Ohio and the Mississippi, obliged him to abridge his Southern tour, and to come in this direction— And he is obliged to embark upon his return home before the next Meeting of Congress. They spent the afternoon and took tea with us— I compared with Charles a few pages of my fathers old Journals with the Copy— Elizabeth C. Adams dined with us.
17. IV:15 Saturday.

My wife, my Son John’s wife and Charles went to Boston this morning and returned to dine— Dr Woodward was here and prescribed a substitute for the cordials to which I have an aversion. My hand continues lame and does not heal well— The Revd. Ray Porter is a Baptist Clergyman of Pawtucket Rhode-Island— He brought me a Letter of Introduction from B. F. Hallett, and solicited a contribution for his Church— He told me it had been built for a Society of Universalists, who soon found themselves unable to maintain their Pastor— The building was afterwards converted into a conventicle of Atheists, with Abner Kneeland for their Preacher— It was lastly purchased by Mr Potter’s congregation who being poor were raising contributions to pay for it— Mr Potter was also the first person who exposed the falsehood of the declaration of the Grand Lodge of Rhode-Island denying the true nature of the Masonic Obligations— Mrs. Frothingham and Horatio Brooks were here before our Ladies had returned. Horatio has just returned from a Voyage to Calcutta Mr Brooks the father went this morning for New-York, where his Son Henry is lying dangerously ill with a bilious fever— Mr Edward Everett went with him— He goes to deliver the Anniversary Φ.B.K. Oration at Yale College, New-Haven— President Quincy was here this afternoon, and took tea with the family— Just returned from a tour to the Niagara and Trenton Falls— Absent three weeks and is much delighted with his excursion— I found this morning in the row of seedling Oaks and Walnuts near the Old Crab-Apple-tree in the Nursery one new Pignut up since yesterday Morning— There may perhaps some in that row which will linger till the next Summer before they come up.
18. V. Sunday— Charles’s Birth day 26.

Change from Summer to Autumnal weather— Cool, dry, North-west wind. Heard Mr P. Whitney in the morning from John 5.39. “Search the Scriptures”—and in the afternoon from Matthew 24.35. [“]Heaven and Earth shall pass away, but my words shall not pass away.” Mr Whitney gave notice that next Wednesday Evening at 7. O’Clock Mr Lucius Manlius Sargent would deliver in the Town Hall, an Address upon Temperance— I began taking three times a day a tonic medicine prescribed by Dr Woodward— I read the 5th. Sermon of the 4th Volume of Saurin, from Colossians 4.6. upon Conversations— A practical, and very excellent discourse— He warns against 5 vices in Conversation 1. Swearing. 2 Obscenity. 3. Back-biting 4. Flattery. 5. Idle talk— One hundred and twenty years at least have passed away since this Sermon was delivered by a French refugee at the Hague in Holland—and it would be a good Sermon to deliver to-morrow, in any City Town or Village of these United States— The Vices of Conversation are perennial— Swearing and Indecency are I believe less prevalent now than they were, a century back—but Slander, Flattery and Idle talk are yet superabundant— Saurin boldly tells his hearers that they are addicted to evil-speaking in the worst extreme, and that all the Vices which he reproves in this discourse are but exemplifications of what he has witnessed among them— This is the true and proper tone of a Christian Minister— Of this we have now too little—and perhaps it can scarcely be expected from Ministers, who depend for their subsistence upon their hearers. The calvinistic preachers are censorious enough; but their vituperation is pointed only against errors of doctrine, as they hold them, without touching upon deficiencies of morals Pope, though a Roman Catholic said that his mode of faith could not be wrong whose life was in the right— The Calvinists reverse this maxim, and think the life cannot be wrong, of him whose Faith is right.— I read also about one Book of Milman’s History of the Jews.
19. IV:15. Monday— Saw Sirius—risen at 4.

Morning visit from Mr Bailey, who introduced a young Irishman named Langtry, recently arrived in this Country and intending to live with an Uncle now residing in the State of Tennessee— Afternoon visit from the Lieutenant Governor, and Mr Pierpont who came to me as a Committee from the Mechanic Institution, to request me to deliver an introductory Lecture, to that Association, next November, about the middle of the Month— The same request was made to me two years ago, by Mr Bowditch and Mr Treadwell— I declined then, and again now— The state of my health now disqualifies me, both for writing and speaking— I told them that I felt myself honoured by the invitation, and would readily comply with it, if I were sure of being able to perform the task— There was every probability that I should not be— They urged me so much that I finally consented to take it into consideration, and to give them a definitive answer within a fortnight or three weeks— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine— John was gone almost the whole day upon a shooting excursion— My hand is still crippled and my rhumatism oppressive. I found in my garden a new Walnut tree, recently but several days up— There is something very remarkable, in the varieties of the first appearance from the ground of Oaks and Walnuts. I feel with more mortification the disability to work in the Garden, than that of writing.
20. IV. Tuesday— Saw Venus after Sunrise.

Harvey Field came to enquire if I would be willing to attend the Convention of Anti-Masons to assemble on the 11th. of next Month at Boston, to nominate a Governor and Lieutenant Governor of the Commonwealth for the next year, or the Caucus of Anti-Masons in this town, to elect delegates for that Convention— I declined both; on the rule which I have prescribed to myself, of refraining from all interference in Elections. Dr Woodward was here, and prescribed again for my complaints; which are not removed. Mr Horatio Brooks and Mrs Charlotte Everett paid us a morning visit. At 7 this Evening with my wife and my Son Charles I attended the wedding of Miss Caroline Whitney, the eldest daughter of Mr Peter Whitney, Minister of the Parish— She was married to MrHill of Jamaica Plains, Roxbury, a widower with two Children. The Ceremony was performed partly by the bride’s father and partly by her brother George. There were sixty or seventy witnesses to the Marriage, and half as many more came in afterwards among whom were my Son John and his wife— We came home about ten O’Clock.
21. V. Wednesday

Morning visits from Mr Sergeant of Philadelphia with Mr Gorham and Mr Crowninshield: and also from Mr and Mrs Barrell— Constant Fobes Oakman the old Revolutionary Soldier was here again, and I told him the answers I had received from the Department of War, respecting his papers that they were not sufficient to obtain his certificate for a Pension— That it would be necessary for him to have a new set of papers forwarded to the Department conformably to the printed Instructions of which I had furnished him with a copy. Mr Bates of the Boston Advocate brought me the proof Sheets of the Stereotype Edition of my
Letters to Edward Livingston, Grand High Priest, of the General Grand Royal-Arch Chapter of the United States—with my Letter in answer to the Committee of the Vermont Anti-Masonic Convention— I had a long Conversation with Mr Bates, and promised to send him the proof-sheets revised before the end of the week— At seven this Evening I attended at the Town Hall, and heard Mr Lucius Manlius Sargent, deliver an Address of an hour and a half upon Temperance—or rather total abstinence from all spirituous liquors— The Meeting was opened by prayer, by Mr Morse, the Minister of the Universalist Church. Mr Whitney was not there— It was a Meeting of the Temperance Society at which Mr George Veasie presided— Two delegates were elected to attend a State Temperance Convention next Month at Worcester— The Town Hall was crowded with an auditory of both sexes, and the Address was listened to with very great attention. It was eloquent and well delivered— About 10. in the Evening I got home.
22. V:15 Thursday— Boston— Quincy

A young man by the name of Atkinson, a Senior Sophister at Harvard University, a stranger to me, came to solicit a loan of 100 dollars to assist him in his studies, and save him the trouble of keeping School— I declined, and advised him to keep School— Visited my Garden and Nursery, but could only observe the varieties of form in which the shellbark and pignut walnuts come up—the gigantic growth of weeds, and the imperceptible progress of other seedling plants— I cannot work— Charles went into Boston and returned to dine; and I rode in with Kirk, and dined at A. H. Everett’s. J. Sergeant—Mr Kennedy and another gentleman from Baltimore, Mr Harrison from Louisiana, a young man from St. Petersburg, President Quincy, Chief Justice Shaw, I. P. Davis, Mr Hale, B. W. Crowninshield, Mr Peabody, with Mrs Everett constituted the company— Conversation not very interesting— Turned, partly upon the charges by recent British Travellers against this Country— The last is a Mr Hamilton, who says that the standard of morality is lower in this Country than in England— I said perhaps imprudently that it would be well for us to consider whether the charge had not some good foundation; and illustrated the question by reference to some recent facts— Such as Bank Stock-jobbing in high places. Sergeant mentioned the case of R. M. Whitney. The lenity towards fraudulent Bankrupts was mentioned &c I came home about 9.
23 V Friday

There was a now deceptive appearance of abundant showers, which passed off with a sprinkling not sufficient to lay the dust. A long and severe drought is to be the character of this Season, which is mitigated by the clearness, coolness and hitherto healthiness of the atmosphere. I attempted to work in my Nursery and Garden, but was very soon obliged to desist— My seedling walnuts are still daily coming up, with extraordinary varieties in the forms of their first leaves. No other new plants now shew themselve—except weeds, the multitude, and growth and towering size of which are appalling— The insolence with which they surrounded and overtop, and eradicate the lowly, modest and scarcely perceptible useful plants, seem to me emblematical of the ways of the world. How much of
the same sort of comparative thrift and prosperity we witness in the world of human life. My time was idled away as it now is without exception— Towards Evening I executed as one of the Executors of Ward N. Boylston a power of Attorney to Joshua Bates of London, to recover the sums of Money belonging to the Estate which Petty Vaughan is receiving and evading to remit, and we empower Mr Bates to give bonds of indemnity to Vaughan, for whatever sums he shall pay over— I executed also a deed of 3/4 of an Acre and one Rod of Land in Roxbury, for 136 dollars 12 Cents, to Samuel G. Goodrich— I carried the two Deeds to Mr Thomas Greenleaf, who took the acknowledgment of them— Dr Woodward was at Mr Greenleaf’s
24. IV:15. Saturday.

My Sons went to Boston and returned before dinner. I attempted again to work in my Garden, but was almost immediately obligated to desist. The Gentlemen named in the margin dined with us. I had also invited Benjamin Gorham, Alexander H. Everett, and Dr. George Parkman, who sent excuses of previous engagements— Isaac P Davis is going next week upon an excursion to the White Mountains in New-Hampshire, and to return by the country on the borders of Connecticut river— He urged me so earnestly to go with him that I have promised to go— I have been much urged by my family to make some such small tour, for change of air and Scene, to improve my health; and although I expect nothing so congenial to my disposition, as my quiet residence here at home, I have yielded to their advice— The Lieutenant Governor Armstrong invited me to attend the Commencement at the Theological School at Andover, next Month; which I likewise almost promised. We had a social and agreeable dinner party, and the company left us about Sunset—
25. IV.30 Sunday

Heard Mr Capen of South-Boston, in the morning from Numbers 22.19. “Now therefore, I pray you, tarry ye also here this Night, that I may know what the Lord will say unto me more”— The discourse was upon the character and history of Balaam; a subject difficult to treat after Bishop Butler. The text of the afternoon was from John 10.18.—“I have power to lay it down, and I have power to take it again.” It is Christ speaking of his own life. I read the 6th. Sermon of the 4th. Volume of Saurin— Upon the beatific vision of the Deity— It is the least agreeable and most unsatisfactory of all the Discourses of this author that I have read. He calls it a thorny subject, and says it has been much celebrated, not to say mystified in the Schools. It is sufficiently mystified by him— His text is from 1. John 3.2.—[“]We know that, when he shall appear, we shall be like him; for we shall see him as he is.”— There is much laborious ratiocination to shew how it follows that we shall be like him, because we shall see him as he is— The closing part of the Sermon is a very eloquent practical application and exhortation to hardened Sinners— And I read part of two books of Milmans History of the Jews— My ardent desire to abstract myself more and more on this day from the cares and troubles and contentions of this world, meets continual obstacles and disappointments— This was a very warm day, and the drought is increasing in severity— Edward Miller, and my nephew John Quincy Adams were here this Evening.
26. IV:45 Monday.

Charles went into Boston this Morning, and returned late this Evening. The weather is so warm, the atmosphere so dry and the roads so dusty that I was all day hesitating whether to undertake the excursion with Mr Isaac P. Davis to the White Mountains of New-Hampshire or not— My hand is yet partially disabled, and my rhumatism has not yet entirely left me— I read a parcel of my father’s old diaries; but it is apparent that the Summer will pass without advancing me at all in the biographical memoir of my father— I have this day been in much agitation of mind, from Sorrows which much be confined to my own bosom— In a life of Vicissitudes, I have had much prosperity; but as life draws towards its close, anticipation has no ground for hope; all is dark and gloomy.— Night is no longer a Season for repose— Morning brings with it no refreshment. It is well for me to prepare the mind for the conviction which cannot fail to be realized that Old Age is the Season of Adversity— Coll. and Mrs Quincy were here this Evening.
27. IV.45. Tuesday.— Boston— Quincy.

I went with Charles this Morning to Boston— Visits to B. W. Crowninshield— T. L. Winthrop, Jos. Hall, Dr George Parkman— I. P Davis— Called at Mr Crufts—he was not at home. His Son Edward who is a young Politician, had a number of Φ.B.K. medals, which he had been charged to procure, and which he is to distribute to-morrow— I was at Charles’s Office; and there saw Mr James H. Foster, who asked me for my proxy to vote at a Meeting of the Proprietors of the Braintree and Weymouth Turnpike to be held next week— I attended a Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society— Judge John Davis presided— Little business transacted— I agreed with Isaac P. Davis to go with him to the White Mountains, and promised to call at his house to-morrow— On the motion of James Savage, a vote of the Society was adopted, requesting me to prepare a Memoir of the Life of William Tudor the younger— Little else was done at the Meeting— Adjourned before one O’Clock— I went again to Charles’s Office; where Dr George Parkman found me, and persuaded me to go and dine with him— No other person there, except his wife and Son— But after dinner a Mr Schmidt a German came in with a Guitar of American invention, upon which he performed with great skill. There came also a Mr Grund, a teacher and professor of Mathematics, and his wife. Afterwards Mr Thomas Coolidge, his wife and her Sister Miss Goldsborough— Lastly judge Peter O Thacher and his wife— Mr Schmidt delighted us with his performance on the Guitar, till Charles came in the Gig for me, and we returned just at the entrance of Evening home to Quincy— I invited my Son John to go with me, upon my excursion to the White Mountains, but he declined.
28. V. Wednesday— Commencement day.
Charles went to Cambridge— John with his wife and two Children went to Boston in the Carriage and I with them— They returned to Quincy to dine— I left my Trunk at Mr Isaac P. Davis’s where I

saw his Son Thomas and him. Met Mr James H. Foster and went with him to my Son Charles’s Office, where I executed the proxy to him to vote for me at the Meeting of the Proprietors of the Braintree and Weymouth Turnpike— Thence I went and passed an hour at the Athenaeum, viewing the Pictures of the Exhibition— There is one of John de Witt and his family, and one of Lord Clive and his family, which amused me much— The principal person in the Clive family is a hindu chambermaid in charge of the infant child— Far more interesting to Spectators than the Lord and Lady. The Picturesque not only levels but inverts distinctions— A Scripture Piece of Martha and Mary in presence of Jesus leaves reminiscences behind— A family piece of George the 3d. and the Royal family, receiving the Duchess of York. 15 men and women in buckram— A copy of the Madonna and Child of Raphael at Dresden, without the other figures in the original was charming, more by recalling the pleasures that I enjoyed in that Gallery in the last Century than for aught else— Portraits full length of T. H. Perkins, and H. G. Otis with his cane good. I lose little of the pleasure I once took in gazing at Pictures— I called twice at Mr Crufts. He was the second time at home— Took a superfluity of fine Plums in his Garden— B. Guild and G. Brimmer came in while I was there— Coming from his house I saw the workmen putting up the Inscription upon the wall of the House which Thomas H. Perkins has given to the Directors of the Asylum for the blind— Met the Carriage returning to Quincy— Met J. Parker. At one I returned to Mr I. P. Davis’s—dined with him and at 2 O’Clock with him and Mrs Davis entered the Stage— We came through Lowell to Nashua 39. miles from Boston, and got in, about 9 in the Evening— We had a crowded Stage partly filled with factory Girls— A Mr. and Mrs Edie from Canada were of the Company— We merely changed horses at Lowell, which since I visited it in 1828 has become a populous Town— But its aspect is not agreeable— We have seen no signs of drought North of Boston.
29. III.30. Thursday.— From Nashua

At four of the Morning we were in the Stage at Nashua—the first town in the State of New-Hampshire; but there were two Stages which came on together from Boston yesterday—and this Morning they changed our Stage companions— We had now six Performers of the Italian Opera, among whom were Mr and Madame Pedrotti, and the base singer Fornasari, a very handsome man and an Elegant. They confined their Conversation almost entirely to themselves and it was altogether in Italian— They had also an enormous load of baggage, and seemingly provisions for a week— We breakfasted at Wilton 15 Miles, and dined at Charlestown 43 Miles from Nashua. There had been much and frequent rain, on the road over which we travell’d and there were no symptoms of drought— The weather was quite cold and rather cheerless.— The country through which we came was not remarkable either for barrenness or fertility— Indian corn was the principal burden upon the fields, and no where a heavy one— Few Pastures— Woods and Rocks in plenty—undulating hill and dale—
some Oats, Rye, Flax, and Buckwheat— A very few Orchards, and occasional moderate sized Beeches, Oaks and Maples; with White and Pitch Pine, Cedar and Hemlock. The most remarkable objects that I see, are the race of men—larger than those of my native State— Much larger than those of England—France, or even Germany— About noon Mr. and Mrs Davis and myself changed our Stage, and returned to the Company we had yesterday. The one in which we had started this morning was overloaded, and threatened much to break down— At Charlestown where we dined we parted from our theatrical company. We turned back and at Bellows falls cross’d the river to the Town of Rockingham and State of Vermont— We came in about five O’Clock, but the afternoon and evening were rainy, and we were almost confined to our Inn— It is kept by Robinson; and here we met Mr Tucker, a brother of Richard D. Tucker— He married a Miss Geyer—and here it was that Frederick Geyer came to close his life— Charles Storer lived here many years in sluggishness; and the Atkinson family are here now but we saw none of them— Mr Hall and Mr Henry, both lodging at the Inn where we are, claimed old acquaintance with me though I did not remember them— We took a short walk after tea, and saw a number of very comfortable and elegant dwelling houses— We spent the Evening in social conversation with Mr Hall, and Mr Henry— I found no time for writing.
30. V:15. Friday. From Bellows Falls to

Before leaving Bellows Falls this morning, I walked with Mr Hall down to the Bridge, and Banks of the river, below the falls, where we step’d over a number of rocks upon which are cut, numerous figures resembling those upon the Dighton rock, and doubtless the work of Indian hands— We departed immediately after Breakfast from Rockingham in the Stage; and among our fellow travellers was the Rev’d Mr. Parker, Minister of the Episcopal Church at Woodstock, Vermont, and two Misses Parker, one, his daughter, and the other a daughter of Mr Samuel D. Parker, County Attorney in Boston, Granddaughter of my old friend Jonathan Mason; we travelled along the Banks of Connecticut river, till we arrived at Windsor where we dined at Petty’s— Here we parted much to my regret from the Parker family, and shortly before Sunset came to Hanover, the seat of Dartmouth College— Here it was the week after Commencement, and the College was deserted— The Square before the College buildings is bordered by four rows of Maple-trees about forty years old— From Hanover where we took up in the Stage a young man named Duncan, who had delivered last week an Oration upon taking his second degree, we came on, still along the Banks of Connecticut river, through Lime to Orford—where we arrived between 8 and 9 in the Evening, where we stopp’d for the Night. 61. miles from the place of our Departure this Morning— Mr Duncan proceeded on this Evening to Haverhill— He appears to be a very well bred and promising young Man— The house where we lodged at Orford is kept by a Man named Wheeler, who told me he had been introduced to me at Worcester in September 1821 when I was going with my father to visit Mr Boylston at Princetown and when we had received in the morning at Framingham, the news that my father’s house at Quincy had taken fire, and narrowly escaped burning down, within an hour after we had left it the day before
31. VI. Saturday.

I was very much indisposed in the Night, and obliged to get up, about 2. O’Clock in the Morning— Still unwell at Breakfast time; but we concluded to proceed at least as far as Newbury Springs. But we have now no regular Stage, and engaged a covered waggon with a pair of horses— Walking before breakfast I measured two or three of a row of Maple Trees about fifty years old, and found the largest of them 5 feet 4 inches in Circumference— We crossed Connecticut river to Fairlee in the State of Vermont and rode 16 Miles to Newbury— Here the house was kept by brothers Atkinson— There was rain great part of the Morning— We found in the garden the Trees covered with the Canada Plum, looking like ripe Cherries, but not quite ripe itself— It had very little flavour to the taste— There are Sulphur Springs and hot Wells at Newbury— Mr Davis and myself took each a warm bath, and drank a Tumbler of the Sulphurated water, which was very weak— After dinner found the house dull; as there were no travellers there, and we determined to proceed in the waggon and pair to Bath—12 Miles— We crossed again the Connecticut river about 2 Miles before we came to Bath on the Ammonoosuck— We reached this place about Sunset— We met here a traveller from Peachum in Vermont, and a person named Low, of Lowell— I was told some of the Gentlemen of the place wished to be introduced to me; but being not very well and much fatigued, I requested to be excused till the Morning— Made a short Evening and retired early— Our route this day as yesterday has been chiefly along the banks of Connecticut river— Less fertile; but still pleasing—generally level; with green meadows—Oak, Beech, Hemlock and Maple Trees.

Day— The early part of the Month I was much indisposed; first with the distressing rhumatism, and lumbago—then with the painful and disabling boil on my hand— The proposition of Mr Davis that I should accompany him and his wife upon this excursion, diversified the incidents of my Life, and has had a cheering influence in the darkness of my declining days— I have continued rising early, and endeavouring to occupy myself profitably, but all is discouraging and gloomy— There is a tide in the Affairs of Men, and when that Tide turns against them in the decline of life—exertion is vain— Prayer is inefficacious— No blessing of Heaven, no smile of Fortune seconds the purest purposes and most unwearied energies— To lie down and die is a privilege denied— A lingering death tortured with disappointments more and more aggravated, and prospects beyond the grave, of no promise for this world, are all that I can see or expect— So it is that prosperous Fortunes go to ruin, and so it is that families are extinguished— There was Mercy for the last days of my father— Will there be any for me?— Yes— I will say in humble hope—if not here—hereafter— Be it mine to ask Fortitude for endurance, and resignation for the divine Will.
